details.purpose: 외래기록, 경과기록, 간호기록과 일반적인 노트 등과 같은 환자를 대면한 후 작성하는 기록

Registrar los detalles documentales de una única interacción, contacto o evento de cuidado entre un sujeto de cuidados y uno o más proveedores de uno o más servicios de salud. Esta interacción puede ser presencial o remota.
details.use: Utilícese como un contendor de nivel de documento para el registro de una única interacción, contacto o evento de cuidados entre un sujeto de cuidados y uno o mas proveedores de cuidados de la salud. El contacto puede ser cara a cara, o por vía telefónicao de cualquier otro medio electrónico. La modalidad puede ser representada, si asi se requiere, por medio del atributo modo de la COMPOSITION. El componente principal de Secciones o Contenido se ha mantenido deliberadamente libre de restricciones. Esto permite que se incluya en la plantilla cualquier Sección (SECTION) o Asiento (ENTRY) apropiado al propósito clínico. Aún cuando se encuentra libre de restricciones en cuanto al contenido clínico, la especificación del COMPOSITION.Encounter agreva valor significativo al permitir la consulta explícita de todos los encuentros conteidos en una historia clínica. El componente de Contexto contiene un slot opcional "Extensión""que puede ser utilizado en el diseño de una plantilla para: -agregar información opcional de contexto, tal como información sobre el episodio, o -permitir la armonización o alineamiento con otros formalismos de modelado tales como FHIR o CIMI, como puede ser la representación explícita de participantes que son generalmente manejados por el Modelo de Referencia en un arquetipo openEHR. Son ejemplos típicos una visita a consultorio, una observación de enfermería o una consulta de telemedicina.
details.misuse: No debe ser utilizado para registrar los detalles de la totalidad de un episodio de cuidado No debe ser utilizado para almacenar información sumaria persistente de un paciente, tale como una lista de problemas o un resumen de medicamentos. No debe ser utilizado para representar el informe de un servicio diagnóstico, tal como un estudio de imágenes o una pruena de laboratorio. No debe ser utilizado para representar el recurso FHIR del mismo nombre ya que existe una diapridad de alcance y propósito.

details.purpose: Registrar os detalhes de uma interação, contato ou episódio de cuidado para a provisão de serviços de saúde entre um sujeito do cuidado e um profissional de saúde. Pode se referir tanto a uma interação presencial quanto à distância.
details.use:
Usar como um documento genérico para registrar detalhes de uma interação simples, contato ou episódio de atenção à saúde entre um sujeito do cuidado e profissional(is) de saúde. O contato pode ser presencial, via telefone ou outro meio eletrônico. A modalidade pode ser identificada, se necessário, através do modelo de referência COMPOSITION/mode attribute.
O componente main Sections/Content foi deixado deliberadamente sem restrições. Isto permitirá que ele seja populado com qualquer arquétipo SECTION ou ENTRY apropriado para o propósito clínico em um template.
Embora sem restrições para conteúdo clínico, especificação de COMPOSITION, Encounter oferece importante valor por permitir pesquisa de todos os Encontros num prontuário do paciente.
O componente Contexto contem um SLOT 'Extensão' opcional que pode ser usado no design do template para: - adicionar informação contextual opcional, como informação do episódio; ou - permitir a harmonização ou alinhamento com outros modelos ou formalismos como FHIR ou CIMI, como uma representação explícita de participantes que normalmente são gerenciados pelo Modelo de Referência openEHR num arquétipo openEHR.
Exemplos típicos são visita a uma clínica, observação de enfermagem ou uma consulta de telemedicina.
details.misuse:
Não deve ser utilizado para registrar detalhes de um episódio de cuidado completo.
Não deve ser utilizado para guardar informações persistentes, resumidas de um paciente, como uma lista de problemas ou resumo de medicamentos.
Não deve ser utilizado para representar o relato de um serviço diagnóstico como exames laboratoriais ou de imagem.
Não deve ser utilizado para representar recurso FHIR do mesmo nome - há uma incompatibilidade de objetivo e intenção.

details.purpose: تسجيل المقابلة على هيئة ملاحظة تقدم الحالة

Registrar, a nivel de documento, una única interacción, contacto o evento de cuidado, entre un sujeto de cuidado (paciente) y un proveedor de servicios de salud (profesional médico, de enfermería, etc.). Puede ser una interacción cara a cara o remota.
details.use: Se debe usar como una definición de documento genérico para registrar información de una única interacción o contacto con un proveedor de salud. Esta definición no especifica la estructura interna de secciones y entradas. Dicha especificación debería hacerse mediante especializaciones del arquetipo o mediante plantillas operativas (Operational Templates - OPT).
details.misuse:
No se debe utilizar para registrar información de un episodio de salud entero.
No debe contener información persistente o resúmenes, como lista de problemas o medicación.
No se debe usar para registrar resultados de laboratorio o imagenología.

term_definitions.items: The data at which the medication course was first ordered or recommended.
The date at which the medication was first issued. 'Issued' refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.
The date at which the medication prescription was last issued. This refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.

The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues.

The data at which the medication was last authorised.The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. Authorisation is generally only given for a limited period or limited number of issues, after which re-authorisation is required.
The date at which the medicaton was first physically dispensed.
The date at which the medication was last dispensed.
The date at which the medication was first administered to the patient.
The date at which the medication was last administered.
The date at which the medication was discontinued.
The date at which the medication was authorised or re-authorised.
The date at which a medication prescription was issued i.e the physical or electronic prescription token was created.
The date at which a medication was dispensed.
The date at which a medication was administered.
The data at which administration of a medication was withheld or suspended.
The date at which the medication order was reviewed.
The date at which the medication order was last reviewed.
The date at which the medication instruction was modified.
This is a medication that has previously been issued, dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.
The medication course has been completed.
This medication order has been superseded by another.
Actions reuulting from the order are to be temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called 'on-hold'.
The medication order has been made but further processes e.g. sign-off or verification are required before it becomes actionable.
Overall summary of the medication course.!
The overall status of this order.
Details of an ingredient used to make up a mixed preparation or infuson.
This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture of infusion is being described.
The chemical has a known and desired effect which is positive.
This chemical is toxic and has no therapeutic effect.
The chemical is active but aids the therapeutic effect of another ingredient.
The ingredient is present to prolong the life of the substance.
The ingredient is used to colour the substance.
The value of the amount of diluent as a real number.
The unit for the preparation diluent.
The role of the ingredient within the mixture or infusion.
The value of the amount of the ingredient as a real number.
The dose unit of the ingredient amount.
e.g 'tablet','mg'. Often coded using a reference terminology such as SNOMED CT.
Further details about the medicatin preparation.
e.g. detailed information about the drug class or intended routes.
The substance is composed of a mixture of ingredients specificied within this order.
The preparation consists of a number of ingredients which are pre-combined by the manufacturer.
The substance is a manufactured product containing a single ingredient.
The substance is an individual ingredient of the medication.
The substance is a manufactured product, containing one or more ingredients.
The strength and form of the medication substance, including details of specific ingredients where required by an ad-hoc preparation or infusion.
This is commonly carried as part of the medicine name and provided by the medicines terminology but in some cases must be specified separately.
The name of the medication substance. This item should be coded if possible.
Usage of substance name will vary according to context of use.
The formulation or presentation of the medication.
The nature of a compound product, consisting of multiple ingredients.
e.g co-codamol is a combination product, wile 50% white soft paraffin + 50% white soft paraffin is an ad-hoc mixture, whose composition is fully specified within the order.
The value of the strength of medication as a real number.
The dose unit of the medication substance strength.
e.g 'tablet','mg'. Often coded using a reference terminology such as SNOMED CT.
The strength of any diluent used as part of the preparation.
e.g. Where a preparation strength is described as '5mg in 10ml', '10ml' is the diluent.
Details of an ingredient used to make up a mixed preparation or infuson.
This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture or infusion is being described.
A text description of the substance where it is not possible to describe this fully using numerical strengths and amounts.
Structured details about the timing of a single use or administration.
The unit which is associated with the Dose amount.
For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The combination of a medication amount and a single medication timing.

For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.
The intended position of this administration pattern within the overall sequence of administration patterns.

For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple administration patterns are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.
The value of the amount of medication administered at one time, as a real number, or range of real numbers, and associated with the Dose unit.
The formula used to calculate the dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor, such as body weight or surface area.
For example: '10mg/kg/day'. The result of this formula would normally be held in Dose amount/unit or Administration rate/duration.
The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.
The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.
The amount of medication to be administered expreseed as a volume. This would gnerally only be used when the medication dose needs to be expressed as both a mass amount and as an equivalent volume.
The name of the event that triggers the activity to take place.
The period of time before or after the named event when the activity should take place. Negative durations can be used to signifify that the activity should be taken before a known event.
e.g. '3 days after onset of menstruation = menstrual onset + 3 days', '2 weeks prior to admission= admission -2 weeks'.
The period of time for which the activity should take place.
The period of time for which the activity should NOT take place.
The number of repetitions of the on/off cycle.
Details of timing schedules repeating over periods longer than a single day.
The activity should only be performed on a single occasion and is not to be repeated.
The number of days per time period on which the activity is to take place.
e.g. "3 times per week", "2-4 times per month".
The activity should take place on a specific date.
The activity should take place on a specific day of the week, with 0 representing Sunday.
The activity should take place on a specific day of the month.
e.g. 'on the 3rd, 13th and 23rd of each month'.
The activity should take place in relation to a specific named event.
A cycle of activity where an on-off pattern is required.
e.g. 'take 3 tablets daily for 1 week, omit a week, then take 3 tablets daily for 1 week, repeat 4 times'
The interval between repetitions of the activity.
The direction should be continued indefinitely.
The direction should be continued indefinitely with a strong recommendation that it never be discontinued.
Structured details about pattern of repetition for each set of daily directions.
For example: 'every 3 days', 'on Thursdays and Sundays', '3 days after onset of menstruation'.
Further details about an ordered item direction.
For example, conditional instructions such as insulin /glucose infusion rates dependent on blood glucose, or detailed administration instructions for particular preparations.
The maximum number of administrations to be given for this direction.
Example: 'Give once only' = 1 or '400mg 12hrly for 3 doses' = 3.
The combination of a medication amount and a single medication timing.
Structured details of a single therapeutic direction for an ordered item, such as a medication or blood transfusion order.
The intended position of this direction within the overall sequence of directions.

For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple dosage directions are expressed, the 'Direction sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab daily for 3 days, (2) 1 tab twice daily for 4 days, (3) 1 tablet for 7 days.
The length of time for which this direction should be applied.

For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.
Details of a healthcare provider organisation.
The unique identifier of the organisation.
The name of a specific department within the organisation.
The identifier of a specific department.
The amount and units of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic good to be used or administered at one time.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Details about the maximum, cumulative dose allowed over a defined period for the ordered item.

For example: 'up to 1gram per day'. This cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of multiple maximum doses that apply to different time periods. Lifetime maximum dose should not be carried here as it refers to multiple orders over time.
The period of time during which the maximum dose is calculated.
Confirmation by the prescriber that the normal dose or other safety limit has been overridden due to exceptional circumstances.
Details about the amount of the ordered item to be dispensed.
This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication dispensing amount to be managed.
Details of authorisation of the ordered item, including supporting local self-administration, issue and endorsement policies.
For example: details of repeat/refill supply. This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication authorisation and re-authorisation to be managed.
Structured description of the site of administration of the ordered item.
Details of the medical device used to assist delivery of the ordered item.
An additional instruction directed primarily at the person dispensing the ordered item.
Example: Detailed instructions for phased dispensing of opiates.
Summary information about use of the ordered item, such as current status or key dates, generally used in non-prescription contexts.

Course summary may be required when transmitting medication information between systems or representing a FHIR Medication statement. For example: as part of a referral, emergency patient summary or discharge communication.
Details about the whole medication order.
The maximum, cumulative amount of medication which should be administered within the allowed period. The unit for this amount is carried in Maximum amount unit.
Permission for substitution with a bioequivalent item.

In many jurisdictions, substitution of an ordered item as a generic form or with a different brand name, which has been determined as bioequivalent, is allowed at the point of dispense or supply. In other cases substitution is assumed and the clinician has to explicitly request non-substitution.
An indicator of the urgency with which the ordered item should be dispensed.

For example 'Urgent'. This is left to be templated or specialised according to local valuesets. Some jurisdictions allow instructions to dispense to be marked as 'urgent' so that the dispensary handles them quickly.
Structured details about the overall preparation including strength, form and constituent substances.
Use this SLOT where the detailed description of the ordered item needs to be explicitly stated. For example: the form, strength, any diluents or mixture of ingredients.
The unit for the maximum amount allowed.
For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Details about the total daily amount of the ordered item expected to be administered.

The total daily dose records the expected effective dose, and thus support titration of an initial low dose towards the effective dose over a period of time. This is not itself the target dose or goal but the actual effective daily dose against that goal. In some circumstances the Total daily dose will be calcuable from computable directions, in others it may need to be manually entered.
The amount of ordered item which will be taken each day if administered as intended.
The dose unit associated with the total daily amount.
The dose units are normally scientific units such as mg, ml rather than 'tablets'.
The reason why an ordered item should not be substituted at dispense.
The date from which the ordered item is permitted to be dispensed for the first time.
May be used to control the time of dispensing of medications with potential for abuse. For example: benzodiazepines or analgesics.
The date after which the ordered item is no longer valid to be legally dispensed.
In some jurisdictions, orders to dispense may have an expiry date after which the prescription may not be dispensed.
The reason for a clinical safety or maximum dose override.
For example: 'Not responsive at maximum recommended dose. Critical situation.', 'Peniciilin is only valid treatment, likelihood of true penicillin allergy is low'.
Description of the reason for recording a total daily effective dose.

For example: 'Hypertension control', 'Target dose 20mg daily'. The description could be used to identify a name, phrase or paragraph about the purpose for recording total daily effective dose, commonly to allow to titration towards a specific target dose. The goal or target dose might be recorded here or more commonly as part of a linked EVALUATION 'Goal' archetype.
Additional structured details about the ordered item not captured in other fields.
Substitution of the medication with a bioequivalent medication is allowed.
Substitution of the medication with a bioequivalent medication is not allowed.
Further details related to dispense directions.
This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication dispensing.

A known or recognised safety issue which applies to this subject and the ordered item, such as an allergy, drug duplication warning or contraindication. This element is normally only recorded when this safety advice is overridden.
Details of structured dose and timing directions.
An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.
The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.
For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'. Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.
Name of the site of administration of the ordered item.
For example: 'left upper arm', 'intravenous catheter right hand'. Coding of the body site with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The technique or device by which the ordered item is to be delivered.
For example: ' via Z-track injection'; 'via nebuliser'. Coding of the method with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.
A parsable, computable text representation of the directions.
Generally this is only used when passing information between legacy systems. For example: '10mg bd; 20mg n' as used by the NHS Dose syntax (in development).
A narrative description of a specific part of overall directions.

In some settings, it is common to split overall narrative directions into more specific segments of narrative. For example in hospital settings, it can be common to split the overall directions into 'Dose amount' and 'Dose timing', both as narrative text. These terms can be applied at template or run-time.
A description of the justification used to calculate a dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor.
Details about medication safety for the ordered item.
An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.

For example: precautions as 'take with food', 'Avoid grapefruit', 'Dissolve in water', 'store in a cool, dry place'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible.
An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.

For example: 'To reduce your blood pressure', 'To thin your blood'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible. If required it is possible to use a LINK attribute to associate this element with, for example, the 'original diagnosis' in a separate Problem list composition but the indication should be explicitly recorded here, as the link target may change over time.
An additional instruction which gives advice on recommended or required monitoring of the ordered item.
For example: 'Please check renal function in 2 weeks'. This data element allows multiple occurrences.
The clinical reason for use of the ordered item.

For example: 'Angina'. Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. It is not intended to carry an indication for administrative authorisation purposes.
The overall therapeutic intent of the ordered item.
For example: 'pain relief'; 'palliative care'; 'low-dose prophylaxis'; 'rehydration'; 'nutritional infusion'.
The date and optional time when it is planned to cease use of the ordered item.
A condition which, when met, requires the commencement of administration or use.

For example: 'Start if symptoms recur'. This is intended for a general pre-condition which should trigger the whole medication course to be started, and not for 'as required' administrations of an ongoing order.
A condition which, when met, requires the cessation of administration or use.
The time period during which the individual/patient has already been using the ordered item as a part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.
For example: To record that the patient had been taking antibiotics 3 days prior to hospital admission, in the context of a 7 day course.
Directions about the dispensing of the ordered item.
Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.
Unique identifier for the medication order.
This data element allows for multiple occurrences to be defined more explicitly at run-time, if required.
The number of administrations of the ordered item that have been completed, as part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.
For example: To record that the patient has taken the two first antibiotic tablets of a three day course, prior to discharge from the hospital to a nursing home.
The date and optional time to commence use of the ordered item.
Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).

e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

Naročilo za zdravilo, cepivo, prehranski izdelek ali drugo terapevtsko sredstvo za določenega posameznika.
*The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.(en)
*For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'. Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.(en)

*The technique or device by which the ordered item is to be delivered.(en)

*Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.(en)

Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.(en)

*Generally this is only used when passing information between legacy systems. For example: '10mg bd; 20mg n' as used by the NHS Dose syntax (in development).(en)
*A narrative description of a specific part of overall directions.(en)

*In some settings, it is common to split overall narrative directions into more specific segments of narrative. For example in hospital settings, it can be common to split the overall directions into 'Dose amount' and 'Dose timing', both as narrative text. These terms can be applied at template or run-time.(en)
*A description of the justification used to calculate a dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor.(en)
*Details about medication safety for the ordered item.(en)
*An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.(en)

*For example: precautions as 'take with food', 'Avoid grapefruit', 'Dissolve in water', 'store in a cool, dry place'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible.(en)
*An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.(en)

*For example: 'To reduce your blood pressure', 'To thin your blood'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible. If required it is possible to use a LINK attribute to associate this element with, for example, the 'original diagnosis' in a separate Problem list composition but the indication should be explicitly recorded here, as the link target may change over time.(en)
*An additional instruction which gives advice on recommended or required monitoring of the ordered item.(en)
*For example: 'Please check renal function in 2 weeks'. This data element allows multiple occurrences.(en)
*The clinical reason for use of the ordered item.(en)

*For example: 'Angina'. Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. It is not intended to carry an indication for administrative authorisation purposes.(en)
*The overall therapeutic intent of the ordered item.(en)
*The date and optional time when it is planned to cease use of the ordered item.(en)
*A condition which, when met, requires the commencement of administration or use.(en)

*For example: 'Start if symptoms recur'. This is intended for a general pre-condition which should trigger the whole medication course to be started, and not for 'as required' administrations of an ongoing order.(en)
*A condition which, when met, requires the cessation of administration or use.(en)
*The time period during which the individual/patient has already been using the ordered item as a part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.(en)
*For example: To record that the patient had been taking antibiotics 3 days prior to hospital admission, in the context of a 7 day course.(en)
*Directions about the dispensing of the ordered item.(en)
*Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.(en)
*This data element allows for multiple occurrences to be defined more explicitly at run-time, if required.(en)
*The number of administrations of the ordered item that have been completed, as part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.(en)
*For example: To record that the patient has taken the two first antibiotic tablets of a three day course, prior to discharge from the hospital to a nursing home.(en)
*The date and optional time to commence use of the ordered item.(en)
*Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.(en)

*Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.(en)
*Details of an ingredient used to make up a mixed preparation or infuson.(en)
*This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture of infusion is being described.(en)
*The chemical has a known and desired effect which is positive.(en)
*This chemical is toxic and has no therapeutic effect.(en)
*The chemical is active but aids the therapeutic effect of another ingredient.(en)
*The ingredient is present to prolong the life of the substance.(en)
*The ingredient is used to colour the substance.(en)
*The value of the amount of diluent as a real number.(en)
*The role of the ingredient within the mixture or infusion.(en)
*The value of the amount of the ingredient as a real number.(en)
*The dose unit of the ingredient amount.(en)
*e.g 'tablet','mg'. Often coded using a reference terminology such as SNOMED CT.(en)
*e.g. detailed information about the drug class or intended routes.(en)
*The substance is composed of a mixture of ingredients specificied within this order.(en)
*The preparation consists of a number of ingredients which are pre-combined by the manufacturer.(en)
*The substance is a manufactured product containing a single ingredient.(en)
*The substance is an individual ingredient of the medication.(en)
*The substance is a manufactured product, containing one or more ingredients.(en)
*The strength and form of the medication substance, including details of specific ingredients where required by an ad-hoc preparation or infusion.(en)
*This is commonly carried as part of the medicine name and provided by the medicines terminology but in some cases must be specified separately.(en)
*The name of the medication substance. This item should be coded if possible.(en)
*Usage of substance name will vary according to context of use.(en)
*The formulation or presentation of the medication.(en)
*The nature of a compound product, consisting of multiple ingredients.(en)
*e.g co-codamol is a combination product, wile 50% white soft paraffin + 50% white soft paraffin is an ad-hoc mixture, whose composition is fully specified within the order. (en)
*The value of the strength of medication as a real number.(en)
*The dose unit of the medication substance strength.(en)
*e.g 'tablet','mg'. Often coded using a reference terminology such as SNOMED CT.(en)
*The strength of any diluent used as part of the preparation.(en)
*e.g. Where a preparation strength is described as '5mg in 10ml', '10ml' is the diluent.(en)
*Details of an ingredient used to make up a mixed preparation or infuson.(en)
*This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture or infusion is being described.(en)
*A text description of the substance where it is not possible to describe this fully using numerical strengths and amounts.(en)
*The direction should be continued indefinitely with a strong recommendation that it never be discontinued.(en)
*Structured details about pattern of repetition for each set of daily directions.(en)
*For example: 'every 3 days', 'on Thursdays and Sundays', '3 days after onset of menstruation'.(en)
*Further details about an ordered item direction.(en)
*For example, conditional instructions such as insulin /glucose infusion rates dependent on blood glucose, or detailed administration instructions for particular preparations.(en)
*The maximum number of administrations to be given for this direction.(en)
*The combination of a medication amount and a single medication timing.(en)
*Structured details of a single therapeutic direction for an ordered item, such as a medication or blood transfusion order.(en)
*The intended position of this direction within the overall sequence of directions.(en)

*For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple dosage directions are expressed, the 'Direction sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab daily for 3 days, (2) 1 tab twice daily for 4 days, (3) 1 tablet for 7 days. (en)
*The length of time for which this direction should be applied.(en)

*For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.(en)
*Structured details about the timing of a single use or administration.(en)
Enota, ki je povezana s količino odmerka.
*For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.(en)
Kombinacija količine zdravil in enkratnega časa zdravljenja.

*For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.(en)
*The intended position of this administration pattern within the overall sequence of administration patterns.(en)

*For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple administration patterns are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.(en)
Vrednost količine zdravil, ki se dajejo hkrati, kot dejansko število ali obseg dejanskih števil in so povezani z odmerno enoto.
*The formula used to calculate the dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor, such as body weight or surface area.(en)
*For example: '10mg/kg/day'. The result of this formula would normally be held in Dose amount/unit or Administration rate/duration.(en)
*The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.(en)
*For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.(en)
*The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.(en)

*The amount of medication to be administered expreseed as a volume. This would gnerally only be used when the medication dose needs to be expressed as both a mass amount and as an equivalent volume.(en)
*The name of the event that triggers the activity to take place.(en)
*The period of time before or after the named event when the activity should take place. Negative durations can be used to signifify that the activity should be taken before a known event.(en)
*e.g. '3 days after onset of menstruation = menstrual onset + 3 days', '2 weeks prior to admission= admission -2 weeks'.(en)
*The period of time for which the activity should take place.(en)
*The period of time for which the activity should NOT take place.(en)
*The number of repetitions of the on/off cycle.(en)
Podrobnosti časovnega razporeda, ki se ponavljajo čez obdobja, daljša od enega dne.
*The activity should only be performed on a single occasion and is not to be repeated.(en)
*The number of days per time period on which the activity is to take place.(en)
*e.g. "3 times per week", "2-4 times per month".(en)
*The activity should take place on a specific date.(en)
*The activity should take place on a specific day of the week, with 0 representing Sunday.(en)
*The activity should take place on a specific day of the month.(en)
*The activity should take place in relation to a specific named event.(en)
*A cycle of activity where an on-off pattern is required.(en)
*e.g. 'take 3 tablets daily for 1 week, omit a week, then take 3 tablets daily for 1 week, repeat 4 times'(en)
*The interval between repetitions of the activity.(en)
*The data at which the medication course was first ordered or recommended.(en)
*The date at which the medication was first issued. 'Issued' refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.(en)
*The date at which the medication prescription was last issued. This refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.(en)

*The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues.(en)

*The data at which the medication was last authorised.The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. Authorisation is generally only given for a limited period or limited number of issues, after which re-authorisation is required.(en)
*The date at which the medicaton was first physically dispensed.(en)
*The date at which the medication was last dispensed.(en)
*The date at which the medication was first administered to the patient.(en)
*The date at which the medication was last administered.(en)
*The date at which the medication was discontinued.(en)
*The date at which the medication was authorised or re-authorised.(en)
*The date at which a medication prescription was issued i.e the physical or electronic prescription token was created.(en)
*The date at which a medication was dispensed.(en)
*The date at which a medication was administered.(en)
*The data at which administration of a medication was withheld or suspended.(en)
*The date at which the medication order was reviewed.(en)
*The date at which the medication order was last reviewed.(en)
*The date at which the medication instruction was modified.(en)
*This is a medication that has previously been issued, dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.(en)
*A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.(en)
*This medication order has been superseded by another.(en)
*Actions reuulting from the order are to be temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called 'on-hold'.(en)
*The medication order has been made but further processes e.g. sign-off or verification are required before it becomes actionable.(en)
*The name of a specific department within the organisation.(en)
